This theorem states that for any two non-zero natural numbers `d` and `n`, the factorization of `d` is less than or equal to the factorization of `n` if and only if `d` divides `n`. Here, the factorization of a natural number is represented by a function that maps each prime factor of the number to its multiplicity in the number. This theorem provides a connection between the divisibility of two numbers and the relationship of their prime factorizations.

type: ‚àÄ {d n : ‚Ñï}, d ‚â† 0 ‚Üí n ‚â† 0 ‚Üí (d.factorization ‚â§ n.factorization ‚Üî d ‚à£ n)
name: Nat.factorization_le_iff_dvd
docString: This theorem states that for any two non-zero natural numbers `d` and `n`, the factorization of `d` is less than or equal to the factorization of `n` if and only if `d` divides `n`. Here, the factorization of a natural number is represented by a function that maps each prime factor of the number to its multiplicity in the number. This theorem provides a connection between the divisibility of two numbers and the relationship of their prime factorizations.

For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ‚Ñï` with `y ^ n < x`.

This theorem provides a condition for the valuation at a prime `p` of the rational number `(n‚ÇÅ / d‚ÇÅ)` to be less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of the rational number `(n‚ÇÇ / d‚ÇÇ)`. This condition is expressed in terms of divisibility by `p^n`. Specifically, the valuation at `p` of `(n‚ÇÅ / d‚ÇÅ)` is less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of `(n‚ÇÇ / d‚ÇÇ)` if and only if for every natural number `n`, if `p^n` divides the product `n‚ÇÅ * d‚ÇÇ`, then `p^n` also divides the product `n‚ÇÇ * d‚ÇÅ`. This statement assumes that `p` is a prime number and that `n‚ÇÅ`, `n‚ÇÇ`, `d‚ÇÅ`, `d‚ÇÇ` are all non-zero integers.

type:
‚àÄ {p : ‚Ñï} [hp : Fact p.Prime] {n‚ÇÅ n‚ÇÇ d‚ÇÅ d‚ÇÇ : ‚Ñ§},
  n‚ÇÅ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    n‚ÇÇ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
      d‚ÇÅ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
        d‚ÇÇ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
          (padicValRat p (Rat.divInt n‚ÇÅ d‚ÇÅ) ‚â§ padicValRat p (Rat.divInt n‚ÇÇ d‚ÇÇ) ‚Üî
            ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), ‚Üëp ^ n ‚à£ n‚ÇÅ * d‚ÇÇ ‚Üí ‚Üëp ^ n ‚à£ n‚ÇÇ * d‚ÇÅ)
name: padicValRat.padicValRat_le_padicValRat_iff
docString: This theorem provides a condition for the valuation at a prime `p` of the rational number `(n‚ÇÅ / d‚ÇÅ)` to be less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of the rational number `(n‚ÇÇ / d‚ÇÇ)`. This condition is expressed in terms of divisibility by `p^n`. Specifically, the valuation at `p` of `(n‚ÇÅ / d‚ÇÅ)` is less than or equal to the valuation at `p` of `(n‚ÇÇ / d‚ÇÇ)` if and only if for every natural number `n`, if `p^n` divides the product `n‚ÇÅ * d‚ÇÇ`, then `p^n` also divides the product `n‚ÇÇ * d‚ÇÅ`. This statement assumes that `p` is a prime number and that `n‚ÇÅ`, `n‚ÇÇ`, `d‚ÇÅ`, `d‚ÇÇ` are all non-zero integers.

If a differentiable function `f` is approximated by a linear map `A` on a set `s`, up to `Œ¥`,

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù E] {s : Set E}

        (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, HasFDerivWithinAt f (f' x) s x) ‚Üí ‚àÄ·µê (x : E) ‚àÇMeasureTheory.Measure.restrict Œº s, ‚Äñf' x - A‚Äñ‚Çä ‚â§ Œ¥
name: ApproximatesLinearOn.norm_fderiv_sub_le
docString:

Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x‚ÇÄ, r * x‚ÇÄ)` and if `P` for `[x‚ÇÄ, r^n * x‚ÇÄ)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x‚ÇÄ, r^(n+1) * x‚ÇÄ)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ`.

type:
‚àÄ {P : ‚Ñù ‚Üí Prop} (x‚ÇÄ r : ‚Ñù),
  1 < r ‚Üí
    0 < x‚ÇÄ ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico x‚ÇÄ (r * x‚ÇÄ), P x) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, (‚àÄ z ‚àà Set.Ico x‚ÇÄ (r ^ n * x‚ÇÄ), P z) ‚Üí ‚àÄ z ‚àà Set.Ico (r ^ n * x‚ÇÄ) (r ^ (n + 1) * x‚ÇÄ), P z) ‚Üí
          ‚àÄ x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ, P x
name: Real.induction_Ico_mul
docString:
Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x‚ÇÄ, r * x‚ÇÄ)` and if `P` for `[x‚ÇÄ, r^n * x‚ÇÄ)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x‚ÇÄ, r^(n+1) * x‚ÇÄ)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ`.

Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `Œ¥ > 0`,
there exists `Œ∑` such that two functions bounded by `Œ∑` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `Œ¥`. One
could take `Œ∑ = Œ¥ / 2` for `p ‚â• 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} (E : Type u_2) {m0 : MeasurableSpace Œ±} (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±) [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  (p : ENNReal) {Œ¥ : ENNReal},
  Œ¥ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚àÉ Œ∑,
      0 < Œ∑ ‚àß
        ‚àÄ (f g : Œ± ‚Üí E),
          MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable f Œº ‚Üí
            MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g Œº ‚Üí
              MeasureTheory.snorm f p Œº ‚â§ Œ∑ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.snorm g p Œº ‚â§ Œ∑ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.snorm (f + g) p Œº < Œ¥
name: MeasureTheory.exists_Lp_half
docString:
Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `Œ¥ > 0`,
there exists `Œ∑` such that two functions bounded by `Œ∑` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `Œ¥`. One
could take `Œ∑ = Œ¥ / 2` for `p ‚â• 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.
